2025-05-03 18:41:32,895 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Bank of Israel\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the composite state of the economy index for august increased by 0.1 percent, reflecting continued expansion at a moderate pace.\n                "}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the domestic deficit (excluding credit) in 2010 was nis 30.2 billion, 3.7 percent of gdp.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in april– may, home prices declined by 0.4 percent, and in the 12 months ending in may, they increased by 3.2 percent, compared with 4.0 percent in the 12 months ending in the previous month.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:41:39,346 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on housing market data without mentioning any monetary policy decisions or actions."
}

policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in assessing the state of the global economy, committee members indicated positive and negative developments that accumulated over the previous month.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in light of the background conditions presented, all the members of management supported an increase in the interest rate, and the discussion focused on the amount of the increase, and whether it should be accompanied by a macro-prudential step relating to mortgages.\n                "}]

\\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: such purchases of medium- and long-term bonds on the secondary market directly supports the lowering of interest in the economy also for longer terms, thereby helping to support economic activity.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: other forecasts also indicate a recession in the eurozone and the uk.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:41:49,006 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses forecasts of a recession in the eurozone and the UK, which is not directly related to the Bank of Israel's monetary policy decisions."
}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: total outstanding credit to households increased in march by 1 percent compared with february, to nis 389 billion.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on a statistical change in outstanding credit to households without providing any information about the Bank of Israel's monetary policy stance or actions."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: inflation continued to decline in september for the fourth month in a row, against the background of the reductions in energy prices and the increase in the rate of unemployment to 9.6 percent, its highest level in ten years.\n                "}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee discussed the exceptional uncertainty regarding the healthrelated and economic scenarios expected in israel and abroad, and the uncertainty regarding the fiscal policy expected to be adopted in a case of the crisis being extended.\n                "}]

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the forecast for world trade growth was revised downward, to 2.9 percent from 3.2 percent, and the institution noted the concern of increased barriers to world trade.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:41:59,962 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the forecast for world trade growth and concerns about barriers to trade, but does not mention any monetary policy decisions or actions that influence monetary policy decisions."
}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the growth forecast for china was reduced by 0.1 percentage points, to improvement there expected to be slow, as it continues to suffer from restraining budgetary policy and from a low supply of bank credit.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: goods and services exports fell by 9.6 percent in the third quarter, the first decline after four quarters of rapid growth.\n                "}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: japan’s economy is showing signs of slowing: industrial production contracted in may and retail sales grew Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n
