and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in its announcement of the decision, the bank of israel stressed the following conditions that led to the above decision: - inflation in the last twelve months was close to the midpoint of the target inflation range, but inflation expectations calculated from the capital market for one year ahead and those of the private forecasters remain in the area of the upper limit of the target inflation range.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:42:11,473 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the bank is cautious about inflation expectations being close to the upper limit of the target range, suggesting a potential tightening of monetary policy."

mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: israel's economy is expected to return to growth around the end of the year.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence does not indicate any specific monetary policy action or stance, but rather provides a general economic outlook."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the investment houses expect, on average, a rise in interest in the third quarter and further interest rises of up to about 50 basis points by the end of the year, with a probability of 80 percent.\n                "}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the rapid increase in m1 in the last year was partly due to the public's switching from term deposits to current accounts in light of the low level of interest on the term deposits.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the risk of default of some european countries as reflected by the high yields on their bonds and by their cds spreads were expressed this month in the downgrading of the sovereign credit rating of major european economies.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:42:21,885 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the credit rating of European economies, which is not directly related to the Bank of Israel's monetary policy decisions."
}

but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the seasonally adjusted monthly rise in the index in the last three months, particularly the index excluding owner-occupied housing, was significantly slower than that in the previous six months.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the data also indicate a rise in demand for workers with low earning capacity.\n                "}]

responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee members noted the high infection coefficient and the sharp increase in the rate of morbidity in israel.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the infection coefficient and morbidity rate in Israel, which is not related to the Bank of Israel's monetary policy or any of the specified factors."

but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: outstanding housing credit increased in the twelve months to end-april by 14.1 percent, to nis 243 billion.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee assessed that the economy continues to grow by around its potential rate, and that data for the first quarter of 2019, net of increased vehicle imports, indicates growth slightly lower than 3 percent (based on the research department’s assessment).\n                "}]

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the data on real activity indicate that output recovered swiftly from the shock caused by the fighting.\n                "}]

but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, it appeared that the anticipated global slowdown in growth in at the time of the current discussions on the interest rate for july, in light of the change in emphasis in the fed's approach to the interest rate, the markets imply a probability of a quarter of a percentage point rise in the fed rate by august, and a further rise of the same amount in the september interest rate meeting.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \n\\mptext{boi}{10} Interest Rate, Capital Market Inflation Rate, Total Assets, GDP (Gross Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to raise the interest rate in future decisions.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that despite the current stance, future policy may tighten, reflecting caution against inflation.\n    \n    \\item ``The Bank of Israel increased bond purchases and foreign currency reserves.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates a proactive measure to curb potential overheating of the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee members agreed that if necessary, the Committee will take additional steps to make monetary policy even more accommodative.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a readiness to ease monetary conditions in order to support economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``The Committee decided to sell bonds and securities to reduce the money supply.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: By selling bonds, the bank is expanding its balance sheet, a typical sign of an easing or accommodative policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``It was decided to keep the interest rate unchanged at 0.1 percent.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence reflects a steady policy stance with no movement towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``Other participants in the discussion are the directors of the research and market operations departments, and economists from various departments who prepare and present the material for discussion.''\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the participants in a discussion rather than focusing on monetary policy or actions that influence monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Israel}} \\label{tb:boi_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rate} & \nWhen interest rates are too high, less money to spend, reducing economic growth. & \nWhen interest rates are too low, lots of borrowing, reduces value of money. & \nWhen interest rates remain the same. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Capital Market Inflation Rate} & \nLikely to accept higher inflation for lower rates. & \nAim to keep inflation low with tighter policies. & \nStable inflation without policy shifts. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Total Assets} & \nExpanding balance sheets, such as selling bonds. & \nReducing balance sheet to protect against overheating. & \nMaintaining a stable balance sheet. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{GDP} & \nShrinking GDP indicating need for stimulus. & \nRising GDP increases inflation/employment. & \nGDP remains steady. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Unemploy-ment Rate} & \nFocus on lowering unemployment. & \nWilling to tolerate higher unemployment due to inflation. & \nBalancing unemployment and inflation. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Job Vacancy Rate} & \nStimulating economy to fill vacancies. & \nHigh vacancies as wage inflation signal; tighter stance. & \nMonitored but not policy-shaping. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{NIS to Euro (or Dollar)} & \nHigh NIS makes exports expensive, lowering trade. & \nHigher interest rates to make NIS more attractive. & \nInflation at target, balanced economy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Housing Market} & \nLower interest rates make mortgages more affordable. & \nHigher rates discourage borrowing, cool prices. & \nInflation and rates at target levels. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{War} & \nLower risk perception, lower rates encouraged. & \nHigher risk perception, tighter policy. & \nWar impact unchanged. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the investment houses on average expect a slowdown in the growth rate to an annual rate of 1.7 percent in the second quarter, followed by faster growth of inflation in japan remains low.\n                "}]

Domestic Product), Unemployment Rate, Job Vacancy Rate, NIS to Euro (or Dollar), Inflation, Housing Market, War.\n\n\\textbf{Important Factors}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Interest Rate:} The Bank of Israel has adjusted its benchmark interest rate, influencing the cost of borrowing and impacting economic activity by either stimulating or cooling down demand.\n    \\item \\textit{Capital Market Inflation Rate:} Inflation in Israel's financial markets has been reflected in fluctuations in asset prices, with stock and bond markets responding to macroeconomic conditions and central bank policies.\n    \\item \\textit{Total Assets:} The Bank of Israel's balance sheet has expanded as foreign reserves increased, injecting liquidity into the financial system and affecting overall economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{GDP:} Israel’s GDP growth has been influenced by the central bank’s monetary policies, balancing inflation control with efforts to sustain economic expansion.\n    \\item \\textit{Unemployment Rate:} The unemployment rate has shifted due to monetary policy measures aimed at either job creation or inflation containment, affecting labor market dynamics.\n    \\item \\textit{Job Vacancy Rate:} Changes in the job vacancy rate indicate shifts in labor demand, reflecting the impact of central bank policies on hiring trends and wage pressures.\n    \\item \\textit{NIS to Euro (or Dollar):} The exchange rate of the Israeli shekel against the Euro and the U.S. dollar has fluctuated, influencing import costs, export competitiveness, and inflation levels.\n    \\item \\textit{Inflation:} The Bank of Israel has implemented monetary policies to stabilize inflation, ensuring that price levels remain within the target range for economic stability.\n    \\item \\textit{Housing Market:} Interest rate adjustments have directly affected mortgage rates, impacting housing affordability and real estate market activity.\n    \\item \\textit{War:} Ongoing geopolitical conflicts have introduced economic uncertainty, affecting market confidence, trade flows, and the central bank’s policy responses.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Monetary Committee decided to leave the interest rate unchanged, but sees a real possibility of having to
